Background:

Democratized Design, development and deployment:

Democratization is the broadening of a provision from a single source to a range or variety of sources. In the context of aviation, this refers to moving the aviation ecosystem to a participatory processes. Democracy allows for feedback and input directly from its constituents (communities, cities). Democratization in aviation implies that the design, development and deployment of flying machines are influenced by and benefit all. There may be unintended consequences to democratization such as are being seen with social media, the diminishing role of experts, growth of misinformation, investment bubbles. Population growth is far outpaced by technology growth as shown in Figure 1. While population growth is poised to plateau at approximately 10B by 2050, technology is developing at an exponential rate. There is an opportunity to engage the public in harnessing technological advancements for mutual benefit avoiding traditional pitfalls. On the one hand this enables development of technology that is desirable and on the other it engages the public in the design process thereby connecting them to the science and technology that flies them. This integrative feature is needed in a world where many are disconnected from the systems they use. The disconnect leads to people being susceptible to misinformation that can be harmful as seen with the latest COVID-19 pandemic. Cloud services and gamification enable this novel engagement between citizen scientists and NASA, providing the opportunity to leverage a diverse population in data generation for AI, vehicle design, ideation and analysis facilitated by NASA. This is called democratized design. New trends in manufacturing and construction such as 3D printing of houses, modular manufacturing [8], offsite construction, and microfactories will allow people or communities to print their own vehicles. These print centers may initially need only the ability to certify production of new vehicles and take into account regulations that need to be adhered to. However, with the increased demand for customization and personalization, the ability to design unique vehicles may present new opportunities. In addition, more accessible development systems will allow new market opportunities for small businesses. This is called democratized development.  

With the increase in income inequality, there is an accepted threat of civil unrest, as evidenced by growing protests related to politics and economics. A focus on Urban Air Mobility that serves urban areas has the potential to exacerbate these differences by providing infrastructure, mobility and access to wealthier passengers. With an estimated 68% of world population living in cities by 2030, poorer populations may remain grounded in even more congested traffic than today, leading to further resentment. Democratized deployment seeks to provide increased access for all through operations that enable mobile services such as schools, groceries, medical supplies. These may be incorporated into the regional and urban air mobility operations. Democratized deployment also considers the use of novel partnerships between aviation and power generation, aviation and housing and civil and military aviation for the public good. 

Decisioning for Ecosystem Wellness:

As the world becomes more interconnected, the complex ecosystems that we rely on such as the transportation (aviation) system, power generation system and residential systems, are more susceptible to disruptions – whether via market forces, acquisition by competitors, climate change disasters or terrorism. Evidence of this is in the impact on airline tourism due to computer chip shortages. The chip shortage that resulted from bottlenecks in semiconductor production resulted in decreased output of new cars that are increasingly dependent on electronics. The pandemic prompted car rental companies to sell vehicles due to lack of demand. When travel restrictions on flying were lifted, the shortage of new cars being produced resulted in a lack of rental cars due to the inability of car rentals to buy new inventory. Thus, travelers wishing to travel to vacation destinations are unable to rent cars and thus may choose not to travel. There is a need to map these ecosystems and their connections so that changes anywhere in the system can immediately be traced to their impacts whether in the present or to forecast potential challenges in the future. This enables decision makers to respond to challenges dynamically and intelligently to maintain the wellness of the ecosystem. Wellness may be defined by desirable properties of the ecosystem such that the system is constantly adjusting to achieve greater wellness. Wellness refers to an objective, yet relative, set of principles that the system strives to achieve either through trade-offs or synergies. These include equitable access, transparent impacts, trust, security and improved health of humans, human systems and the environment. With the growth in non-traditional aviation markets and the increased access to personalization, there is a need to automate regulations, certifications, reviews and to recognize and trace changes in requirements to assure the public of safety.

Long Answer (rationale) 

There is no one definition (they tend to be circular), wellness and health are typically defined by attributes or description as we attempted in the attached. Additionally, when talking about natural ecosystem health and wellness, you are generally trying to sustain the ecosystem’s structure in the face of changing conditions (Resilience) to preserve its functions. These functions are felt by the systems, subsytems (species) and impact their health and wellness. If the functions need to change, then changing the structure is a necessity. In nature this happens in a feedback loop involving adaptation, extinction and climate change.  

Ecosystem health is defined as “the state or condition of an ecosystem in which its dynamic attributes are expressed within the normal ranges of activity relative to its ecological state of development” (van Andel and Aronson, 2006), while ecosystem integrity is “the state or condition of an ecosystem that displays the biodiversity characteristic of the reference, such as species composition and community structure, and is fully capable of sustaining normal ecosystem functioning” (SER, 2002) 

What are the dynamic attributes? 

What are normal ranges? Do we want to maintain this or move toward optimal? 

What is its state of development and how to map normal ranges to each state? 

Ecosystem integrity is about the structure of the ecosystem. 


Adaptation from James Moore’s concept of Ecosystem: A community supported by the structure of interacting (through resources and ideas) organizations/institutions and individuals/people —the organisms of the business world. The economic community produces goods and services (functions) of value (and consequence) to people, who are themselves members of the ecosystem. The member organisms also include suppliers, lead producers, competitors, and other stakeholders.  

 

What this means then is subjective and changes over time. There is no agreement on whether to track GDP, wealth, happiness, prosperity. So I suggest skipping this layer. 

We can use trend analysis across demographics to determine what people want/need to move them (individuals and society) up Maslow’s hierarchy. 

Foundational needs should supersede other needs when distributing resources. 

  • Physiological 
  • Security/Safety 
  • Belonging 
  • Esteem 
  • Self-actualization 

There are some attributes that the ecosystem should try to address for the individual and these can be derived from the CDC, WHO etc. and relate to Maslow’s. 

Health and wellbeing: The CDC (Centers for Disease Control) summarize attributes of well-being as the “presence of positive emotions and moods (e.g., contentment, happiness), the absence of negative emotions (e.g., depression, anxiety), satisfaction with life, fulfillment and positive functioning”. The various aspects of wellbeing include physical, mental, economic, social, developmental, active, emotional, psychological, life satisfaction, domain specific satisfaction and engagement. https://www.cdc.gov/hrqol/wellbeing.htm#three. According to the WHO (https://www.who.int/data/gho/data/major-themes/health-and-well-being), "Health is a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity." Some of the major health topics identified by WHO include radiation, pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, blood products, hepatitis of unknown causes I children, tobacco, vaccines, chemical release and oil fires, home care for families and caregivers, refugee and migrant health, air quality, autism, food fortification, deafness, radioactivity in food, drug resistance, tropical diseases, stress, chemical poisoning (lead), ageing. 

Societal problems being targeted:

Inequity – wealth; access to resources such as food, water, education and knowledge, medicine; access to opportunity; access to tech; regulations and impact on society and cities. Labor shortage (specifically in aviation) – migration to commercial space; tech; rise of social media. Potential for civil unrest: Rise of populism due to socioeconomic divides (needs of the many at odds with the ‘establishment’); perceived lack of transparency; role of tech and media in divisions. In this report, we are focusing on the inequities related to medical (health) coverage, services, access and the issues related to labor shortages that compound the inequities.

Problem space: - Need: Health and Wellness - Capability: Aviation/AAM/Commercial space - Trends: Democratization, Distributed systems, Decisioning systems

Description: New trends in democratization such as IoT, wearables, blockchain, AAM, and citizen science are changing the technical capability landscape. Decisioning systems are coming online with the rise of artificial intelligence, blockchain and the cloud. In healthcare, trends indicate a focus on mental health, life extension, gene editing/therapies, AI drug discovery and nanomedicine, consistent with trends in other industries aimed at miniaturization, deep exploration, speed and safety. At the same time, perceived threats to privacy, increasing pandemic risk and spread through aviation and rising income inequality are creating greater cause for concern for global health and wellness. Aviation plays a major role in the medical supply chain while also being the cause of physical and mental health issues. Fragile supply chains and labor shortages pervade aviation and the health and wellness industry. Will changing demographic and generational trends open new opportunities that leverage democratization and decisioning systems?

Solution Vectors: distributed trust, distributed orchestration, government role in regulation, leveraging lessons from developing world

Prompt: How might the aviation industry improve/provide in-flight medical capabilities? (to account for the growing trans-oceanic medical tourism industry))

  • SubProblem:
    • If in-flight incidents become more common, how might they be handled with minimal loss of life?
  • Sources:
    • Medical Tourism Statistics and Facts | Health-Tourism.com
  • Why is this a problem?
    • The aviation industry has taken on new roles given the ability to provide increasingly complex medical care in flight. Reliance on these increasingly more competent capabilities allows travel where it previously was restricted due to health reasons. However, in flight medical capabilities have their limitations, and unforeseen events can turn a standard flight into a medical emergency. 83% of US adults said it is difficult to afford or the costs are unreasonable for prescription drugs. 30% do not take medicine as prescribed due to costs.
    • The average spending per visit now rests at $3,000 - $10,000 per tourist.
    • Estimates show growth of costs in the future. Medical tourism is a last resort to treat an illness like cancer that may be too aggressive or invasive for treatment back home.
    • We assume that the use of medical tourism (transportation to treatment) will increase as costs of treatment increase and access to advanced treatment by rural and disparate communities decreases.
    • We also assume that the environment in the plane is not conducive to proper medical response at this time. We are not concerned with “airplane hospitals,” but with commercial transit for medical tourists that need emergent treatment (for inflight emergencies) or inflight treatment/stabilization to get to their destination.
    • MISSING IMAGE
    • MISSING IMAGE
  • What capabilities may be needed to address the problem?
    • Improved mobile health care provided by increasingly comprehensive suite of medical technology. Flying after surgery can increase the risk for blood clots, including deep vein thrombosis. If you get chest or abdominal surgery do not travel by air for at least 10 days to avoid risks associated with changes in atmospheric pressure. People who get cosmetic procedures of the face, eyelids, or nose, or who have had laser treatments should wait 7–10 days before flying.
    • For in-transit medical support, we suppose that future systems might need additional light-weight machines or monitors. They might need extra refrigeration or custom storage for medical materials. They might need in-flight wifi with dedicated bandwidth for emergency or medical communications or monitoring. They might need modified seating space or alterations to cabin pressure settings/standards to accommodate environmental risks. They might need modified doors or removable seating to accommodate temporary changes to get patients on or off. They might need changes to air-quality (e.g. immunocompromised patients).
  • What trends might enable problem exploration and solution?
    • https://www.mddionline.com/design-engineering/big-prospects-medical-device-miniaturization
    • There is a notable and significant trend towards miniaturization of health care tools such as diagnostic and treatment capabilities.
    • Further, the introduction of automated systems and artificial intelligence can provide guidance even to professional caregivers.
    • Telehealth is making professional healthcare support more accessible and available.
    • Such developments are an extension of the revolution in healthcare that has enabled both airlift helicopters as well as ambulances to do much more for the patient in transit then previously conceivable.
  • Reach - How many people, communities are going to be impacted or are impacted by the problem?
    • Scores: 10M and 100k
    • The overall community affected by this change in health care availability is relatively small. However, to that community this is a critical and life changing issue. U.S. outbound medical tourists are thought to make up about 10% of the worldwide total. Data from a U.S. government survey suggest that 150,000 to 320,000 U.S. travelers list healthcare as a reason for traveling abroad each year, or between 0.2% and 0.6% of all outbound U.S. air travelers.
    • We believe that a large portion of medical tourism is currently related to prescription drugs. As trends above continue, we expect more in-plane medical needs, but it is difficult to determine total size over the next 15-30yrs. 10M globally might have moderate improvement to safety from solving this problem. 100k per year might be able to access lifesaving, critical procedures.
  • Impact - What is the scale of the impact? (high, medium, low)
    • See above. Split the population between moderate improvement and critical to safety.
    • Scores: 3 (10M) and 4 (100k)
  • Confidence - How confident are we in the impact and reach determinations?
    • There’s so much we don’t know about the denial of travel that COULD be air-based. Who wants to fly for treatment but can’t? But we are concerned that this may be an underestimation. We could not find clear data on future projections for this problem.
    • Scores: 3 “Somewhat Confident” (10M), 3 “Somewhat Confident” (100k)
  • Effort – what is the effort/scale needed to address? Wickedness? CAS-worthy?
    • One possible approach to this issue maybe the integration of the technology being developed for astronaut healthcare for long duration missions with commercial aviation sources. This may provide a new level of complexity in what is available in aviation for health care.

How might aviation mitigate growth of drug resistant bacteria due to heavy metal manufacturing and usage? (advanced manufacturing, airport safety protocols, and aircraft design) 

  • Sibling Question: 
    • How will aviation mitigate growth of drug resistant bacteria due to increased usage of antimicrobials in response to COVID-19? (airport safety protocols, and aircraft design) 
  • Why is this a problem?
    • Drug resistant bacteria is propagated by the use of heavy metals (lead, mercury, and silver) because of mining and transportation usage. Bacteria have evolved to resist the presence of these heavy metals, producing traits that also shield them from antibiotics. 
    • Normally heavy metals are lethal to bacteria because of the free emission of ions that disrupt cell functions. 
    • Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health and development threat. It requires urgent multisectoral action in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). 
    • WHO has declared that AMR is one of the top 10 global public health threats facing humanity. 
    • Misuse and overuse of antimicrobials are the main drivers in the development of drug-resistant pathogens. 
    • Lack of clean water and sanitation and inadequate infection prevention and control promotes the spread of microbes, some of which can be resistant to antimicrobial treatment. 
    • The cost of AMR to the economy is significant. In addition to death and disability, prolonged illness results in longer hospital stays, the need for more expensive medicines and financial challenges for those impacted. 
    • Without effective antimicrobials, the success of modern medicine in treating infections, including during major surgery and cancer chemotherapy, would be at increased risk. 
    • “The site contained a strain of bacteria resistant to 70 percent of antibiotics tested against it.” heavy metal toxicity. Ultrasound was needed for the diagnosis of obstetric and intra-abdominal conditions. Further, screening for a ride range of cancers needs to be increased notably."

    • https://www.epa.gov/caddis-vol2/metals

Rather, to the extent that autonomous and automated systems become an aspect of health care, a new set of medical ethics concerns arise. Patient monitoring is necessary during medical transport. If this involves an autonomous or automated transportation system, then That patient information resides with in that autonomous or automated system and it needs to be handled appropriately. Timely delivery of supplies and services by whatever means is a core foundation of health care. If an autonomous or automated system fails in its designated function, that failure just impacts individual health care and an understanding of responsibility or liability is needed_. Broadly speaking, issues involved are:

      • Local regulations, laws 
      • Decision making 
      • Medical transport 
      • Liability 
      • Maximizing patient care 
  • What capabilities may be needed to address the problem? 
    • There are two aspects of this problem. The first is technical regarding the capability of an autonomous or automated system the carry out its function in an optimized fashion minimizing impact to patient health. The second is the framework of legal and societal restrictions that impose upon the autonomous or automated system a layer of functionality that, for example, ensures confidentiality of patient information or appropriate response in emergency condition. 
  • What trends might enable problem exploration and solution? 
    • One trend is that health care on a local level is becoming increasingly more distributed and advanced. The complexity of health care provided by, for example, emergency air evacuation services has increased over the years. The overall trend is that more can be done locally rather than in a centralized hospital setting. A second trend is changes in the air transportation system is envisioned over time to allow new forms of both personal air transport_ as well as also delivery of supply and materials. A third trend is the advancement of artificial intelligence and data handling systems that may be able to not only allow new types of vehicle operations, but also an ability to handle information in a more complex and situationally appropriate manner.

    • The overall impact varies depending on the type of transport. Related to emergency transport and care, the population may be limited and more concentrated in rural areas. However other forms of medical transport are much more common. For example, professional transport a patient from one health care facility to another is a relatively common occurrence within parameters dictated by legal and health insurance regulations. Further, if air transportation and medical supplies using, for example, autonomous or automated drones becomes a common occurrence, then the impact on the overall health care system on the performance of these technologies can be significant and broad based.

title: Reflections on Possible Future Problem Spaces Related to Geoengineering and Aviation

storage.value:
Reflections on Possible Future Problem Spaces Related to Geoengineering and Aviation

Current understanding of possible technical approaches to geoengineering fall into two categories:

  • Carbon Dioxide Removal (CDR), and possibly other greenhouse gasses (GHG[1]): In this approach existing and newly created carbon dioxide is removed from the atmosphere, sequestered at production time, or otherwise reduced as a component of the atmospheric makeup.  This approach will likely require significant ramp up time, in the order of decades as reduction efforts progress and desired effects are reached, and will result in lasting temperature reduction effects[2].  If for some reasons CDR efforts stop effects will continue for some time while GHG begin to build up again.
  • Solar Radiation Management (SRM): This involves reducing the amount of sunlight impinging on the surface so as to reduce the overall temperature, either by reflecting sunlight before it reaches the planet (as in orbital mirrors) or by altering the atmosphere to reflect more sunlight (by injecting aerosols as in a volcanic eruption example). This approach would result in quick cooling not needing a slow ramp up as CDR to produce results but if stopped the effect created does not last.

These approaches are not exclusive and both can be pursued independent or in conjunction to each other. There are significant uncertainties and not well understood possible negative effects in both of them.

 

Climate change and any geoengineering interventions performed as a result will impact aviation at many levels, in areas such as technology, logistics, operations and perhaps existential.  For example it is known that aircraft contrails can aid in reflecting sunlight (a form of SRM) so we have seen sources comment on the feasibility of changing current aircraft routes to both create the effect in desired locations and to also allow aircraft to not interfere with each other’s contrails so as to extend said effect.   There could be pressure to accelerate the transition to sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) or other energy modes.  Either of these would significantly impact current models of operations and value/cost.

 

But while these effects will impact aviation it is clear to us that aviation as a whole can also have significant impacts on the climate change/geoengineering problem space.  Aviation is a factor in GHG production but it could also be well positioned as a tool platform for active geoengineering interventions and/or passive sensing and tracking of its effects both of which are needed.  A tool platform with a long and rich history of experience in its use and operations.  Given the level of uncertainties around geoengineering interventions the availability of such a well understood platform is rather helpful.

 

Looking Ahead

If we fast forward 50+ years from now and imagine that a regional or global geoengineering effort is initiated, aircraft will most likely be required to play major roles particularly if SRM is performed.  One of the most promising method for SRM is to inject aerosols into the atmosphere via aircraft.  While still a complex, large and costly operation it is more feasible, cost vs. viability, than orbital reflectors for example.  This is due to the already existing levels of experience around aircraft deployment and operations. Opportunities for current vehicles and/or new, high flying, long loiter platforms, possibly unmanned are likely. Previous (McClellan 2010) and current (Smith 2022) geoengineering cost analyses of various concept of operations are available, and can serve as anchor points for new studies that predict the costs and concepts of future aviation-geoengineering operations, as well as to determine their feasibility and estimate the costs and impacts of inaction.  

If we assume that aircraft will be involved in the deliberate dispersion of particulate materials in the atmosphere to alter climate, it is possible that new actors will require the aircraft industry to actively participate in data and sample collection campaigns that inform the geoengineering operations. If this is true, the aircraft industry would experience significant impacts that may include but are not limited to new flight paths, and changes to aircraft hardware/software upgrades, as well as requirements to accommodate air sampling, collection, and analysis platforms, instruments, and technologies.  

We predict that environmental monitoring of the air that planes fly through - as well as the impacts they have on the atmosphere as they fly through it - will need to be closely monitored at the highest spatial and temporal resolutions possible to inform geoengineering models and subsequent operations, which would naturally make all aircraft in the National Airspace prime candidates for participation.  This scenario could actually develop to some extent even if no geoengineering interventions is undertaken locally but as a method for detection and attribution of possible interventions undertaken by others[3].

We note that requiring commercial vehicles to accommodate sensor platforms that serve a government geoengineering function may be very challenging to achieve. If industry is not favorable to implementation of these notional operational and technical changes, entire new fleets of aircraft may be required: to monitor impacts and implement the desired outcomes of geoengineering efforts as directed by future actors. A “GeoForce” of aircraft, manned and unmanned.  A much simplified but analogous example are the fleets of water-spraying UAVs in Bangkok, Thailand in 2019 (figure 1 and 2), whose exploratory mission was to reduce PM2.5 in the local atmosphere (Simon, 2019).    


   

Figure 1 and 2: UAVs dispersing materials to reduce PM2.5 polution. (From Simon, 2019)

Regardless of what level government and industry play in a government-sponsored geoengineering effort, huge quantities of samples and data will be collected, and we envision the need for a new open-access geoengineering data and sample repository.

Whether climate change-induced or geoengineering-induced, evolving and increasingly extreme weather patterns will continue to impact aviation. For the industry to be able to continue providing reliable products and services to customers worldwide, the industry will need to adapt and incorporate climate change awareness across all operational and business models.

    1. Actors: Research Institutions. LMIC (Low/Middle Income Communities).

    2. Demographics Impacted: Various LMIC around the world.

    3. Why did this become a trend: There has not been a well-defined discourse on the proper ethical considerations to take when conducting 10+ year studies in LMIC around the world.

    4. Consequences of trend:  

      • Assumption that the duration of research activities may have important implications for the ethical obligations of research institutions and investigators conducting their studies in low-resource settings.
      • Should be a favorable risk/benefit ratio for the community in question.
      • Two previous studies (Belsky and Richardson, 2004 and Richardson, 2007) have demonstrated that duration affects the strength of the researcher-participant relationship, can generate greater obligations to provide additional benefits to those involved in the studies. Community may grow significant dependence on the services or economic opportunities associated with the research engagement.
      • Six considerations
        • Long-term community benefit
        • Issues surrounding autonomy and communal consent process
        • Discontinuation of the research
        • Health systems impacts
        • Economic impact of research participation
        • Evolution of participating institutions during the course of the research period
      • May be challenging to maintain fair benefits to the community
      • Concerns that providing additional care & services may compromise the validity of the original study.
      • Open discussion at the onset of research very important.
      • Opinion of Emanuel et. Al. (2004) that for research conducted in developing countries, researchers have an obligation to ensure fair benefits to the community and fair distribution of profits resulting from the research.

    5. Temporal Characteristics: Ongoing for long research periods of 10+ years.

    6. Geographical Distribution: Various LMIC.

      9. Increased scrutiny for Scope 3 Emissions (all emissions in a companies value chain, direct and indirect) (Environment, Economic)
      10. Increasing Distrust among Nation States (Economic, Political)
      11. Increasing Energy Consumption (Economic, Technical)
      12. Increasing Nationalism (Economic, Political, Social)
      13. Increasing Unilateral Action on Climate Change (Environment, Political, Technical)
      14. Manufacturing Footprint & Facilities Reevaluated & Change (Economic)
      15. More Unstable Economic Cycles (Economic)
      16. Quiet Quitting Increases (Economic, Social)
      17. Rise of Anti-Work (as currently defined) and Pro-Labor Movements (Economic, Social)
      18. Rise of Megacities (Economic, Political, Social)
      19. Urbanization of Africa leads to massive increase in GHG (Green House Gas) Emissions...  Or Not (Economic, Environment, Political, Social)
      20. Widening Geographical Inequalities (Social)
    2. We can see how all these trends can combine and create a rather scary future.
      1. Increasing Energy Consumption and Demand will make the Climate Change situation worse.
      2. Previously available resources will begin to disappear or become more difficult (expensive to get)
      3. This lack or difficulty in obtaining resources causes economies to reconsider their presence in various markets and geo locations.  They may shrink, move to other locations or abandon the market space completely.
      4. Such retreats, abandonments, reorganizations convulse the market in new and unforeseen ways.
      5. This all reflects back into tensions in societies, old social contracts (and the views that made them possible) are reevaluated or also abandoned exacerbating QoL and economic issues.
      6. The shattering of social contracts, expectations and norms make people want to move to better locations this tied to climate change forced migration increases overall populations movements from stressed environments to those perceived to be better.
      7. GeoPolitical situations change so drastically (whether slow or fast the magnitude is more critical, allies are abandoned, new partnerships are sought, positions are reversed and so on) new power blocks emerge and form.
      8. Old allies no longer trust each other, social and economic pressures cause some losers (and winners) in this scenario to turn inwards and become more hard line nationalistic in order to maintain any sense of control substituting pride in nation, an aggrieved, victim mentality to coalesce around "hope" for improvements and action.
      9. Desperation becomes more as nations try to solve the problem anyway they can and in doing so create friction points around which new skirmishes and conflict arise.
      10. Economic block struggle more and more to survive and begin to collapse, shrinking from the global to the regional.
    3. In general Climate Change will rework the global maps (both physically as in rising sea levels but also politically and economically).
    4. In principle this problem can be tackled at its source but there is no political focus or power center that can move enough resources to make any significant impact.  So whats left consolidates more and more around resources and their value creating new large centers for these populations.
    5. Warfare could escalate to progress reducing levels and wars of attrition develop and spiral into the stone age.
    6. Fossil Fuel economy chains collapse in some places and shrink back into these large ("lucky") new population centers.
    7. Energy could go back to more mechanical means, water wheels, loaded kink springs (Paulo Bacigalupi), sails, human, in certain areas both economic and geographical.
    8. These large population centers could supply a "new" source of power: Human Labor.  Large Pools of Human Labor.
  3. Looking at these Three Technical Trends:
    1. Natural Language Modeling continues to improve and eventually becomes part of the normal UI/UX to machines and processes
    2. Safety Cases Develop that use AI as part of the Safety Logic Case Chain
    3. AI begins to move from the Cloud to the Edge with Digital Twins (and in so doing aids Industry in developing an Industrial Metaverse)
    4. And considering their impact on Climate Change/GeoEnginering one can consider both ways:
      1. That perhaps the greater streamlining an optimizing of industrial process can be used to alleviate the climate problem.  Or,
      2. That the greater optimization of industrial processes will spur on the need for more and more energy consumption.  More control inspiring more want.
      3. Alternatively (on the gripping hand) greater insight and control into the industrial process will certainly be of great value to transition to more green economies BUT that transition is still a big transition no matter how much insight and efficiency one has.
